Like its predecessor, the ping g15 irons graphite shafts are oversized irons designed for players seeking maximum forgiveness. However, several changes have been made which PING believes should make the club even more forgiving. The epicenter of the technological advances of Ping G15 Irons is the new Custom Tuning Port ("CTP". While the G10 had a CTP, PING engineers reshaped and repositioned the CTP to save seven grams. The weight savings of a thinner face allowed the engineers move weight to the perimeter - particularly the toe - to improve forgiveness for off-center hits as well as increase MOI. PING believes that these changes of Ping G15 Irons provide the proper structure and support to ensure distance control and solid feel.

On the following pages you'll find photos of each new model from the two lines, plus a little info about each. Keep in mind that the Ping G15 series is aimed at golfers seeking maximum forgiveness and high-launch attributes; the i15 series is aimed at golfers who want more workability.

Try Best to Get Big Forgiveness with Mizuno Iron

Do you know Mizuno JPX 800 irons? Yes, you should know this excellent clubs, I used it for several years, it's really great. Now I spare its details with you.

Gap Wedge and Sand Wedge utilize a solid power bar design for greater control and pinpoint accuracy. Multi-material cavity badge provides tuned impact sound with enhanced feel

and sharp looks.Durable double nickel chrome plated finish. Modified U-grooves produce the ideal spin rate for maximum playability in all conditions.4-7 irons deliver the

highest allowable COR (coefficient of restitution) and low deep center of gravity for amazing distance and forgiveness. Aggressive Triple Cut sole for consistent forgiveness

from all types of lies and playing conditions.

The mizuno jpx 800 irons are Mizuno's first range that bring the exotic JPX technology platform to the European market. "Hot Metal" incorporates a new manufacturing process for a

thinner, more uniform iron face. An exotic pocket cavity with multiple thickness levels and an external power bar add the highest measurable levels of forgiveness (MOI) achieved

in a Mizuno iron to date. Modified U-Grooves produce maximum spin rates within 2010 Condition of Competition rules.

Just like the S2 forged, however, once we were deep into the testing process, it became clear that putting the mizuno jpx 800 driver Pro along side the others in that review just didn

â€™t make for a fair fight. The head is less bulky than the standard JPX-800 (narrower sole, thinner top line), it features less offset, and visually, to me anyway, it looks a

bit more refined than the average game improvement iron. Because the JPX-800 is part of Mizunoâ€™s game improvement series, it shouldnâ€™t come as any real surprise that the lofts

are 1Â° strong when compared to the MP-53 and 2Â° stronger than the MP-68. For some additional perspective consider the lofts of the JPX-800 are actually, on average 1Â° weaker

than those of the previously reviewed Cobra S2 forged, and by the time we get to the 7 iron (the club we use to conduct our performance tests), the JPX-800 is actually 2Â°

weaker than the equivalent Cobra S2.

Whatâ€™s interesting is that while shot for shot, the JPX-800 wasnâ€™t as long as others weâ€™ve tested, our testers were generally more consistent with their distances. This

general consistency of distance prevented the shorter shots from wiping out the longer ones. In the end, while not quite S2 Forged numbers, our testers posted excellent overall

distance scores with the callaway golf clubs. Like the MP-53, the JPX-800 features Mizunoâ€™s Triple Cut Sole (most visible in the leading edge grind), which helps to ensure consistent

performance from a variety of lies.

From a distance perspective, the more traditional lengths and lofts do lead to decreased distance. In direct comparison to the Cobra S2 forged, most of our testers lost between

3 and 10 yards of total distance. Our highest handicapper, Dave, however, actually increased his raw distance average by 15 yards, which helped to offset the loses by our other

testers.
